### Supporting Point 3
*   One of the primary benefits of case studies is their ability to provide context to abstract theories. In the field of organizational behavior, for instance, a study on the implementation of a new management system may rely heavily on real-world examples from companies that have successfully or unsuccessfully implemented such systems (Eisenhardt & Graebner, 2007).
*   Case studies also allow researchers to explore the nuances and complexities of human decision-making in the context of organizational behavior. For example, research has shown that employees' perceptions of their work environment can significantly impact their motivation and job satisfaction (Hackman & Oldham, 1976).
